The Robert E. Lee Boyhood Home Virtual Museum

Ann Hill
Carter Lee

Ann Hill Carter Lee

Robert E. Lee's mother, Ann Hill Carter Lee, was the great-granddaughter of Robert Carter (1663-1732), one of America's earliest men of wealth. Carter's wealth came from service as land agent for the English Proprieter, Lord Fairfax. As such, he collected rents on the millions of acres owned by Fairfax in Virginia. His position gained for him an estate of some three hundred thousand acres and made him so powerful that he became known as "King" Carter. His wealth, filtered through several generations, was the ultimate source of Ann's inheritance.

Ann's father was Charles Carter, one of Virginia's wealthiest planters. His home called Shirley Plantation was located on the south side of the James River near Richmond, VA. Ann came from a distinguished family. It is probable that she was known personally to all seven Virginian signers of the Declaration of Independence, to all of whom, save one, she was related by ties of consanguinity or marriage.

Comparatively little is known of Ann personally. It is believed that the likeness shown above is hers because the brooch in the picture, bearing a likeness of George Washington, is similar to one known to have been hers. Ann was born in 1773, though exactly where is not certain. Ann was the daughter of Anne Butler Moore, Charles Carter's second wife. She was the tenth of twenty-three children born to Charles' two wives. So, though of a wealthy family, she could not see herself as particularly unique. Charles, nonetheless, displayed a lively interest in the welfare of each of his children. It may be safely inferred that she posessed a strong sense of family. Similarly, she was a religious person with a strong belief in the existence of a just and benevolent God.

Ann was not physically strong. She is said to have suffered from narcolepsy, a disease which made her, along with many persons of her time, even those not so afflicted, fearful of being buried alive. There is even a legend that she was, indeed, thought dead and nearly so buried. As early as 1806 she writes that she was becoming an invalid. During her stay at the Oronoco street home, she needed help negotiating the stairs. Ann apparently suffered from tuberculosis for an indeterminant time preceding her death.

After the death of his first wife, the "Divine" Matilda Lee, mistress of Stratford Hall, thirty-seven year old, Virginia Governor and Revolutionary War hero, Henry "Light-Horse Harry" Lee came to Shirley to woo Maria Farley one of Ann's friends living there. Upon his being rejected by Maria, twenty year old Ann set about capturing him for herself, although he was seventeen years her senior. Charles Carter was aware of Lee's reckless reputation and constant financial difficulties. He, therefore, opposed the match, citing Lee's then consideration of an offer of a generalship in France's Revolutionary armies. When Lee rejected the offered French commission, Carter lost the reason he had used for stopping the marriage. The wedding took place at Shirley on June 18, 1793. Although consenting to the marriage, Charles did ensure that Lee could not touch any of Ann's inheritance. A near contemporaneous account of this courtship and its aftermath is provided in a linked 1821 letter.

By the time of the birth of Robert, her fifth child [Algernon Sydney, the eldest did not survive], Henry Lee was in deep financial trouble. He was being pursued by his creditors and Stratford Hall, where the Lee's had gone to live, was being denuded of property and servants to satisfy their demands. Ann was sick with a cold and saddened by the death of her father when Robert Edward Lee, named for two of her brothers, was born on January 19, 1807. In 1809, her husband was twice imprisoned for debt. Circumstances reduced Ann to delivering food in person to Lee's prison for lack of servants and teaching her children herself in Stratford's Great Hall, where they could find both heat and light from the fireplace. About this time Ann was offered asylum for herself and her children by the husband of her late sister, Mildred. Ann refused to abandon her husband, choosing to maintain her home and family despite Henry's imprisonment. Upon his release she did insist on the right to choose their residence. Ann chose to move to Alexandria, VA, eventually renting William Henry Fitzhugh's home at 607 Oronoco Street. In this location, she had numerous family members nearby and her children were thus assured an education at their neighboring plantations and later the Alexandria Academy.

In 1813 Henry's career and life in America came to an end when he went into virtual exile in the West Indies after being nearly killed and permanently injured in a political riot in Baltimore, MD. Left on her own, Ann husbanded her inheritance to provide for her children writing infrequently to Henry, who had even in good times seldom been much at home.

Of her children, Carter, the eldest, was closest to his father and was the addressee of most of his letters, though oft unmailed, from exile. Carter was also favored by Ann's brother William, who paid for his education at Harvard. The younger sons were not so fortunate. Smith, the second son, chose to go to sea, joining the US Navy. Ann Kinloch, the eldest daughter and second eldest child spent much of her time away from home seeking medical attention for a condition, probably tuberculosis of the bone, which eventuated in the loss of her arm. This left to Robert, the eldest remaining child, the principle responsibility for assisting Ann during most of the Lee's stay in Alexandria. In his mother's words he became "both son and daughter" to her. There can be no doubt of a close personal attachment between mother and son. However, Nagel* concludes Ann had no favorites.

Upon Robert's departure for West Point, Ann moved with her two daughters from Alexandria to Carter's home in Georgetown, DC.where he practiced law. Finally, her health deteriorating, she moved to the home of William Henry Fitzhugh's widow at Ravensworth in Fairfax County, VA. There she died on June 29. 1829, but not before seeing Robert return after graduation from West Point, Carter and Smith with established careers in law and the Navy, daughter Ann Kinloch married and daughter, Mildred, engaged.

Originally interred at Ravensworth, Ann's remains are now, along with those of her husband and son, in the Lee Crypt at Washington and Lee University, Lexington, VA.

* The above narative is primarily based upon Paul C. Nagel's The Lee's of Virginia. From the Lee Boyhood Home Museum Docent's Guide I have also quoted from a reprint of Cazenove G. Lee Jr.'s article on Ann Hill Carter from the William and Mary Quarterly, vol. 16, series 2, 1936, pages 417-419. WJS

It's tough to put your finger on an exact "job title", but more, you
become a well rounded person. I always stress in situations, that the experience
of working on projects with a completely diverse group of nationalities has
been a gift. You learn how different cultures approach a certain solution
to a problem. Also, ECS & P majors usually have personalities that are
creative and often outgoing. I was in a situation where I was working for the
concierge service of American Express. I saw that a huge part of travel
done by clients was to Paris and the rest of France. I saw a niche needed for
an expert in developing relationships with vendors and restaurants in France.
I consulted with clients. That restaurant relationship experience later lead
me to doing restaurant relations for Goldman Sachs in NYC. Fun!! That
company did some major layoffs, and we were all let go. I've recently
moved back to Los Angeles and am in the process of presenting some ideas for
product development for a chocolate company. I saw something that was
missing and am hoping to create a position for myself.
The best advice is for students to get their first jobs out of school in
companies with big, powerful names. Get that experience and it tends to
open doors to other opportunities.
I'm happy to talk to students. For me, I was 34-35 years old when I was at
AUP. Perhaps it's a nice thing to appeal to the older student who is
either in the midst of a career change or just looking for new experience. I was
lucky enough to have a few other students my age, whom to this day, we
remain best friends while in Miami, New York and Los Angeles.
Furthermore, EVERYONE in the USA is impressed with people who have been
educated outside of the USA. I've realized that the majority of people out
there have a fear of picking up and getting out of their comfort zone. So,
there are a ton of things to chat about.

24-Nov-2004 
 

Ann Hill
Molecular Microbiology and Immunology L220, Oregon Health Sciences University, Portland, United States

Immune Evasion by Herpesviruses; AIDS Vaccine Development

Ann Hill
Department of Molecular Microbiology and Immunology
Tel.: (503) 494-0763
Fax.: (503) 494-6862
Email: hillan@ohsu.edu
Go to: personal webpage

My laboratory studies immune control of chronic virus infections, concentrating on the cytotoxic T cell (CTL) response. We have two major interests; firstly, murine cytomegalovirus (MCMV) as a tractable model of immunity to herpesviruses, and secondly, vaccine strategies to induce an effective CTL response to HIV. MCMV encodes several proteins which interfere with the MHC class I pathway of antigen presentation to CTL. We have identified a 34kD protein which binds to class I in the ER and travels with it to the cell surface. We are investigating the function of p34 using biochemical, cell biological, and cellular immunological approaches; using wild type MCMV and a virus specifically lacking p34. We are committed to establishing the MCMV model in sufficient detail to determine how the virus persists in the face of the immune response without causing disease. To this end, we have undertaken to identify the major CTL epitopes in MCMV. The HIV vaccine project uses mouse models to explore basic principles and the rhesus monkey-SIV model to test vaccine strategies. Our aim is to create high numbers of high avidity CTL in response to vectored SIV proteins, and to identify factors which correlate with reduction of virus load after challenge with virulent SIV. We have developed a herpes simplex (HSV) based vaccine which lacks ICP47, the HSV-encoded inhibitor of antigen processing, and which expresses SIV-gag. We postulate that a persistent virus may result in higher numbers of CTL over time. We are using a variety of other vectors in sequential immunizations to attempt to increase the relative immunodominance of the gag antigen in the heirarchy of vector CTL epitopes.

Selected publications

Hill, A., Jugovic, P., York, I., Russ, I., Bennink, J., Yewdell, J., Ploegh, H., and Johnson, D. (1995). Herpes simplex virus turns off TAP to evade host immunity. Nature 375, 411-415.

A mouse cytomegalovirus glycoprotein, gp34, forms a complex with folded class I MHC molecules in the ER which is not retained but transported to the cell surface. EMBO J. 16, 685-694.

Hill, A.B. and Masucci, M.G. (1998). Avoiding Immunity and Apoptosis: Manipulation of the Host environment by Herpes simplex virus and Epstein-Barr virus. Seminars in Virology 8, 361-368.

Ann Hill
Assistant Professor, Department of Molecular Microbiology and Immunology, OHSU

Phone: (503) 494-0763
Fax: (503) 494-6862
E-mail Dr. Hill


MAJOR AREAS

Interference with immune recognition by herpesviruses.


PREVIOUS POSITIONS

1979 - 1982 Resident Medical Officer, Sydney Hospital, Sydney, Australia
1983 - 1984 Immunology Registrar, St. Vincents Hospital, Sydney
1990 - 1994 Oxford Nuffield Dominions Medical Fellowship
1993 The Royal Society Travelling Fellowship to Japan
1995 The Arthritis Foundation post-doctoral fellowship, MIT, Boston, MA


EDUCATION

  • M.B., B.S. (1979) University of NSW, Sydney Australia
  • Ph.D. (1990) Australian National University

RESEARCH INTERESTS

My laboratory investigates T cell immunity to viral infections. Our main interest is in herpesvirus immune evasion genes- how they function, and what effect this has on the immune response to the virus and the virus infective process. We use murine cytomegalovirus (MCMV) as our main model.

Cytomegalovirus (CMV) is a ubiquitous infection, infecting approximately 70% of adults in the US. CMV infects in childhood and establishes lifelong infection, usually without symptoms. Immunity to CMV occupies a surprisingly high proportion of the immune system throughout life: around 4% of CD4+ and 10% of CD8+ T cells in chronically infected people are specific for CMV, probably more than for any other virus. This high number of T cells is thought to be maintained by recurrent virus activity, which nevertheless normally remains below the threshold of detection. However, if immunity is compromised, CMV rapidly reactivates and is a main cause of morbidity in most clinically immunocompromized states. It thus appears that the chronic equilibrium between CMV and host involves a lot of activity on both virus and host sides. The long term goal of my lab is to understand this equilibrium and its consequences for the host.

Like all herpesviruses, CMV encodes a series of genes that enable it to avoid detection by cytotoxic T cells. We use the murine model of CMV infection to understand how these genes impact the ability of the immune system to control the virus. MCMV encodes three immune evasion genes, m4, m6 and m152. m6 and m152 prevent MHC class I reaching the cell surface, but m4 has a novel means of action. It interacts extensively with class I in the ER, forming complexes that are detectable in digitonin lysates of cells but are disrupted by NP40. A small amount of m4 forms NP40-stable complexes with class I; these complexes travel to the surface of the cell where they remain stably associated.

The projects in my lab can be grouped into three broad areas:
(1)understanding the molecular mechanisms by which m4, m6 and m152 interfere with antigen presentation
(2)understanding the normal immunobiology of MCMV infection
(3)understanding the impact of interference with antigen presentation on the immunobiology of CMV infection.

(1) understanding the molecular mechanisms by which m4, m6 and m152 interfere with antigen presentation
This project is currently mainly focused on understanding the mechanism of action of m4. One of the main projects in my lab is to determine at which site (the ER, the cell surface, or both) m4 is able to interfere with antigen presentation. The effect of MCMV infection on the function of the peptide loading complex in the ER, and on the function of the immunological synapse at the cell surface, is being investigated.

(2) understanding the normal immunobiology of MCMV infection
A major effort has been put into identifying the immunodominant CTL epitopes for B6 mice. To this end we have almost completed cloning the MCMV genome into an expression vector, and are screening CTL clones and splenocytes from infected mice. We will investigate the relative immunodominance of the various epitopes over time. We also need a method to monitor virus activity during chronic infection, and various approaches are being explored. There is surprisingly little information about how MCMV spreads from one host to another, and we are investigating this to establish a reliable model of host to host spread. We are also interested in the role of dendritic cells and direct infection versus cross-presentation in driving the large CTL response, and the effect of the NK cell response on CD8s.

(3) understanding the impact of interference with antigen presentation on the immunobiology of CMV infection.
We have obtained from our collaborator Ulrich Koszinowski a series of MCMV mutants lacking each of the immune evasion genes, alone and in combination. We are investigating the size and specificity of the CTL response to each of these viruses, and the ability of the virus to establish latent infection. Surprisingly, avoiding antigen presentation does not seem to be necessary for the ability of the virus to establish latent infection, raising the question as to what the real function of these genes is. This is being further explored, looking at their effect on transmission to new hosts, and possible prevention of immunopathology.


RECENT OR IMPORTANT PAPERS

Ann Hill (1948– )
Advocate
Social Work 1978

Ann Hill founded Creative Lifestyles, an organization serving developmentally disabled youth in the South Bronx. Seeing that the population was served primarily through agencies based outside of the Bronx, Hill went into New York City public schools to document the need for community-based services. She spoke at school gatherings and ultimately recruited up to 500 parents and their children, documenting their needs; she took the documentation to Albany. Today, Creative Lifestyles has two day programs and two to three state of the residential facilities. She was ahead of her time.

Submitted by Kenneth Graves, School of Social Work 1978, who is solely responsible for the content.

72 - St Ann's Hill
Event Details
BoroughRunnymede
TownChertsey
Date07/11/2004
Start14:00
End15:30
CategoryGuided Walks, History
Join Phil Jones of the Surrey County Archaeological Unit for a 1 mile, 1.5 hour walk around St Ann's Hill near Chertsey. The Iron Age Hill Fort built in this prominent location overlooking the Thames Valley has dominated and controlled settlement and many activities in the area. Meet at 2pm at the car park along Old Coach Road (leads north from St Ann's Hill Road). Grid ref. 026 674

The intrepid crew of the cemetery shoot. (Photo by Amy Lynn Best, which explains her absence from the picture)


The Scene: In the opening sequence of the film, Ann Hill (Gina Preciado) receives a visit from The Executive (Francis Veltri), who has her describe a recent attack in a cemetery.



Special thanks to Yahoo!Geocities completely random crashing that has forced me to retype this page from memory months after creating it originally! Thank you, thank you, Geocities!


When I started this website, I swore that it would not be a forum for bitching and complaining about the way certain events transpire. Therefore, I will not mention our less-than-successful shoot at Pittsburgh Filmmakers, nor the fellow filmmakers who usurped the room we had reserved two weeks in advance in order to film pick-up shots of the fight scene between Sister Bliss and Adam. I may not be the nicest guy in the world, but back in the day when I was a student, if I discovered that, having taken over one of the unused classrooms on a weekend, that another member had needed it, and all I was using it for was to have potential actors fill out forms, and knowing that there were plenty of other rooms available, I would have said, Oh, yeah, no problem man. Theres only three people in here. Ill move them out. I would not have said, But we reserved this room last week, and I came in early to arrange all the chairs in nice rows. And I dont want to move these people out of there because actors need to concentrate and besides I reserved this room two weeks ago! I might even have said, If you hang on a few minutes, lets give these guys time to finish what theyre doing. You wanna get one of the other rooms open for me, Id appreciate it. Sorry about the mix-up. I certainly would not have said, Hey, man, this rooms, like, crucial to our audition space. What, you want me to make these guys wait outside? Sorry.

So, I wont talk about any of that. Except to say that independent filmmakers  even students  are all in the same boat. We may get cranky, and we may not feel that each project is on the same worthiness level as another, but theres no excuse for being rude and irascible, particularly when asked politely for something, and particularly when youre trying to share facilities. Also remember that every filmmaker is using a crew that consists of people who know other people. If you piss off one member of the crew, you are bound to piss off a dozen more, and soon your name has spread like a virus throughout the virtual crew bloodstream and woe unto you should you ever need a favor from someone  anyone  connected in any way with that crew. So, as a word of advice, be polite and professional to each other at all times. Thank you. And yes, we did get those pick-up shots, in another room, where the lay-out doesnt match, but if we keep the editing tight, chances are it will work. If it doesnt, Ill know who to thank.



Enough vitriol. Lets move on to the next day, Sunday. Sunday was much better.

The opening sequence of the film is one of the few scenes to remain consistent during all drafts of the script. We knew from the beginning that we would be blasted by hard-core horror fans for seemingly ripping off George Romeros classic Living Dead trilogy -- which, in many cases, we are, and well be up front about this -- so it was always our intention to be blatant right off the bat, in order to say, Here, well save you the trouble; this is what we are doing! The sequence involves The Executive interrogating a woman who claims to have been attacked by a zombie in a graveyard. (The only change we made to the scene was moving it from an ordinary interrogation room to Ann Hills house itself, which we feel serves the scene better  the idea of Godcorp invading someones home  and out of convenience, which Ill explain in a minute). You get to see, via black and white flashbacks, Anns attack and subsequent escape from this Cemetery Zombie. This was going to be our tribute to the original Night of the Living Dead and we wanted to be as blatant as possible.

Originally, our plan was to approach Bill Hinzman, the original Cemetery Zombie. Its been thirty-odd years since Bill made his debut as the classic ghoul, and though he doesnt much look like his 1967 self (no, his reprisal of the role in NOTLD: The 30th Anniversary Edition doesnt count!), we thought it would be a nice twist. However, when the time came to shoot the scene, Mr. Hinzman was unavailable.

No matter. We found our perfect cemetery zombie in the form of longtime friend and sometime-co-conspirator, Dan Franklin. Dans the lead singer of the Pittsburgh rockabilly band The Filthy Bastards (and this isnt the first time weve had a bastard in our film. Lead guitarist Mike Athey appears as a guard in The Climax, and drummer Casey Larocca is a zombie in The Antonia Trowbridge Sequence). Dan is naturally emaciated, pale and sickly, with the dead, hollow stare of a zombie to begin with. In fact, in order to make him appear dead, makeup artist Bill Homan would most likely have to make Dan look healthier and then work from there. (Sorry, Dan, those are the best insults I could come up with!) Once we got him into a tight suit, Dan looked so much like the Hinzman of years gone by, the results were frightening.



Our Ann Hill was found in Gina Precciado, who also performs in the improv comedy troupe, The Amish Monkeys with executive producer and lead villain Francis Veltri. Gina is a versatile actress and comedienne, and was absolutely perfect as the angry and frustrated Ann.

To cap off the day, good friend Bill Hahner happens to be an expert on Night of the Living Dead, and was able to recreate some of the key shots from that films cemetery sequence. Bill was also generous enough to lend us his home, which was right across the street from a beautiful cemetery (which is why we rewrote the scene to be set in Anns home, rather than try to shoot the scene on two different days in separate locations. See how things work out?)

We shot all the outdoor stuff on black and white reversal film, and the results are striking and beautiful. The choice of filmstock actually backfired on us at first. We had ordered B&W negative, but the supply house sent us reversal instead. Rather than send it back  which would have been out of the question, as the house dragged its feet on shipping  we opted to use what we had and try to adjust, as reversal has much lower latitude and margin of error than negative. Once shot, we then discovered that our local lab, WRS, Inc., no longer processes b&w reversal, so we were forced to find another lab that would. Ultimately, we found Cinelab in Boston, which did a fine job with a great turnaround time.

The shoot in the cemetery itself was great fun. Bill Hahner just glanced around, found locations that would well-match the cemetery of the original and we went to work. (Again, we actually scouted locations at the Evans City cemetery, where the original NOTLD crew shot, but discovered that over the years, the cemetery had changed and no longer looks the way it does in that long-ago film.) It wasnt a busy day, so there werent many gawking on-lookers. The true fun came when Dan had to attack Gina. We threw Gina on the ground, then threw a perfect stranger on top of her. She couldnt wait to tell her husband!

My one regret was not getting a great gag on film. The closer we get to the end of this two-year-plus ordeal, the sillier weve been getting. During one sequence, Dan had to chase Gina through the maze of headstones, and after two or three shots of this, we joked that we should have gotten a shot of her chasing him. It would have been a hilarious outtake, but, alas, we ran out of time.

All in all, it turned out to be a great, productive weekend, with Sunday being a welcome contrast to Saturdays fiasco.



All pictures copywright 2000, Amy Lynn Best.

Ann Hill Duin is Vice Provost for Instructional Technology and University Partnerships and a Professor of Scientific and Technical Communication at the University of Minnesota. Her over 60 publications include books and journal articles on the design of online learning environments and distance education research. Honors include Best Curriculum Innovation in the Teaching of Writing from EDUCOM, IBM AS/400 University Partners Development Award, Distinguished Teaching Award at the University of Minnesota, Distinguished Alumni Award from Waldorf College, and outstanding article awards from EDMEDIA and the National Council of Teachers of English. Beginning July 2000, Dr. Hill Duin will be Associate Provost and Director of Extended and Continuing Education at Iowa State University where she will lead distance education initiatives.

Fieldnotes

St.Ann's Hill Fort (aka Eldebury [Oldbury] Hill Fort) – 27.7.2003

As Juamei said, not the most evocative Hill Fort in Britain, but a pleasant walk if you can try to forget the constant hum of the traffic from the nearby (but unseen) M ways. The whole of the open area covers 57 acres in all.

The info board gives a tiny bit of info on the hill "St.Ann's Hill takes its name form a chapel built around 1334 dedicated to St.Ann. Its original name was Eldebury (Oldbury) Hill with an old fort, and there are traces of old earthen defences on the top. The most notable resident of the Hill was the radical politician Charles Fox whose house was opposite the present main entrance. The hill was presented to the Local Authority by Baron Camrose of Longcross and opened by the Rt.Hon. Neville Chamberlain MP in June 1928".

The ramparts are not particularly strongly preserved. Best on the west side. Also strong on the East side but the track up to the Reservoir Cottage (at the top of the hill) makes them look a bit false.

NB – The roads towards the hill are signposted to a point but overgrown at the crucial turnoff onto 'St.Anns Hill Rd' so look for the road sign of that name. 		Posted by pure joy
27th July 2003ce
Link

[visited 30/3/3] Another tree clad hillfort imperceptable as such unless you look closely. There is a sort of bank-ditch combo kinda encircling the hill, but not cared for and in one place replaced by huge girt concrete steps. The ever present distant roar of the M25 / M3 / Heathrow really detracts from this otherwise pleasant little retreat from North Surrey.

The best viewpoint in the place affords a nice view of a couple of rivers / lakes in the foreground and Heathrow just past them. We can only imagine what it was like even 100 years ago compared to now, I'm guessing somewhat more relaxing...

So in all, very nice I'm sure for the residents of Chertsey, somewhat less appealing for those of us who entered this area just for this experience. Go to Oldbury instead, you'll be glad you did! 		Posted by juamei
1st April 2003ce
Link

Miscellaneous

Add miscellaneous
'Prehistoric London' by Nick Merriman (1990 – ISBN 0112904475) mentions that "St.Ann's Hill near Chertsey has evidence of occupation as early as about 750 BC". Which dates it to a similar time as Caesar's Camp on Wimbledon Common, and most probably earlier than Caesars Camp, Keston, Loughton Camp and Ambresbury Banks. Posted by pure joy
27th July 2003ce
Edited 27th July 2003ce

Dr Ann Hill, Executive Officer
Dr Ann Hill (Executive Officer) is a vegetation scientist with a background in business and training. She holds a first class honours degree in biological and environmental science and a doctorate in woodland ecology. She is a member of the British Ecological Society, the British Bryological Society and the British Lichen Society and is the Worcestershire County Biological Recorder for bryophytes. Ann has a broad knowledge of applied plant ecology and has specialist skills in several areas, including botanical surveying, bryophyte identification, and woodland and grassland aspects of the National Vegetation Classification.

Ann Hill
MMI> Faculty Listing> hilll
 


Ann Hill
Assistant Professor, Department of Molecular Microbiology and Immunology, OHSU

Phone: (503) 494-0763
Fax: (503) 494-6862
E-mail: hillan@ohsu.edu


MAJOR AREAS

Interference with immune recognition by herpesviruses.


PREVIOUS POSITIONS

1979 - 1982 Resident Medical Officer, Sydney Hospital, Sydney, Australia
1983 - 1984 Immunology Registrar, St. Vincents Hospital, Sydney
1990 - 1994 Oxford Nuffield Dominions Medical Fellowship
1993 The Royal Society Travelling Fellowship to Japan
1995 The Arthritis Foundation post-doctoral fellowship, MIT, Boston, MA


EDUCATION

  • M.B., B.S. (1979) University of NSW, Sydney Australia
  • Ph.D. (1990) Australian National University

RESEARCH INTERESTS

My laboratory investigates T cell immunity to viral infections. Our main interest is in herpesvirus immune evasion genes- how they function, and what effect this has on the immune response to the virus and the virus infective process. We use murine cytomegalovirus (MCMV) as our main model.

Cytomegalovirus (CMV) is a ubiquitous infection, infecting approximately 70% of adults in the US. CMV infects in childhood and establishes lifelong infection, usually without symptoms. Immunity to CMV occupies a surprisingly high proportion of the immune system throughout life: around 4% of CD4+ and 10% of CD8+ T cells in chronically infected people are specific for CMV, probably more than for any other virus. This high number of T cells is thought to be maintained by recurrent virus activity, which nevertheless normally remains below the threshold of detection. However, if immunity is compromised, CMV rapidly reactivates and is a main cause of morbidity in most clinically immunocompromized states. It thus appears that the chronic equilibrium between CMV and host involves a lot of activity on both virus and host sides. The long term goal of my lab is to understand this equilibrium and its consequences for the host.

Like all herpesviruses, CMV encodes a series of genes that enable it to avoid detection by cytotoxic T cells. We use the murine model of CMV infection to understand how these genes impact the ability of the immune system to control the virus. MCMV encodes three immune evasion genes, m4, m6 and m152. m6 and m152 prevent MHC class I reaching the cell surface, but m4 has a novel means of action. It interacts extensively with class I in the ER, forming complexes that are detectable in digitonin lysates of cells but are disrupted by NP40. A small amount of m4 forms NP40-stable complexes with class I; these complexes travel to the surface of the cell where they remain stably associated.

The projects in my lab can be grouped into three broad areas:
(1)understanding the molecular mechanisms by which m4, m6 and m152 interfere with antigen presentation
(2)understanding the normal immunobiology of MCMV infection
(3)understanding the impact of interference with antigen presentation on the immunobiology of CMV infection.

(1) understanding the molecular mechanisms by which m4, m6 and m152 interfere with antigen presentation
This project is currently mainly focused on understanding the mechanism of action of m4. One of the main projects in my lab is to determine at which site (the ER, the cell surface, or both) m4 is able to interfere with antigen presentation. The effect of MCMV infection on the function of the peptide loading complex in the ER, and on the function of the immunological synapse at the cell surface, is being investigated.

(2) understanding the normal immunobiology of MCMV infection
A major effort has been put into identifying the immunodominant CTL epitopes for B6 mice. To this end we have almost completed cloning the MCMV genome into an expression vector, and are screening CTL clones and splenocytes from infected mice. We will investigate the relative immunodominance of the various epitopes over time. We also need a method to monitor virus activity during chronic infection, and various approaches are being explored. There is surprisingly little information about how MCMV spreads from one host to another, and we are investigating this to establish a reliable model of host to host spread. We are also interested in the role of dendritic cells and direct infection versus cross-presentation in driving the large CTL response, and the effect of the NK cell response on CD8s.

(3) understanding the impact of interference with antigen presentation on the immunobiology of CMV infection.
We have obtained from our collaborator Ulrich Koszinowski a series of MCMV mutants lacking each of the immune evasion genes, alone and in combination. We are investigating the size and specificity of the CTL response to each of these viruses, and the ability of the virus to establish latent infection. Surprisingly, avoiding antigen presentation does not seem to be necessary for the ability of the virus to establish latent infection, raising the question as to what the real function of these genes is. This is being further explored, looking at their effect on transmission to new hosts, and possible prevention of immunopathology.


RECENT OR IMPORTANT PAPERS

1. Hill, A.B., Jugovic, P. , York, I., Russ. I., Bennink, J., Yewdell, J., Ploegh, H andJohnson, D.: Herpes simplex virus turns off TAP to evade host immunity. Nature, 1995, 375:411-415.

2. Kavanagh, D.G. and Hill, A.B.: Evasion of cytotoxic T lymphocytes by murine cytomegalovirus. 2001. Seminars in Immunology,13: 19-26.

3. Daniel G. Kavanagh, Marielle C. Gold, Markus Wagner, Ulrich H. Koszinowski and Ann B. Hill. The Multiple Immune-evasion Genes of Murine Cytomegalovirus Are Not Redundant: m4 and m152 Inhibit Antigen Presentation In a Complementary and Co-operative Fashion. 2001 J. Exp. Med. 194: 967-977.

4. Daniel G. Kavanagh, Ulrich Koszinowski and Ann B. Hill. The murine cytomegalovirus immune evasion protein m4/gp34 forms biochemically distinct complexes with class I MHC at the cell surface and in a pre-Golgi compartment. 2001 J. Immunol. 167: 3894-3902.

5. Gold, M.C., Munks, M.W., Wagner, M., Koszinowski, U.H., Hill, A.B.*, and Fling,,S.P. The murine cytomegalovirus immunomodulatory gene m152 prevents recognition of infected cells by M45-specific CTL, but does not alter the immunodominance of the M45-specific CD8 T cell response in vivo. 2002, J. Immunol. 169: 359-65. *corresponding author.

6. Yewdell, J. and Hill, A.B. Viral interference with antigen presentation. 2002, Nature Immunol. (in press).

7. LoPiccolo, D.M., Gold, M.C., Kavanagh, D.G., Wagner, M., Koszinowski, U.H. and Hill, A.B. Effective inhibition of Kb- and Db-restricted antigen presentation in primary macrophages by murine cytomegalovirus. 2003, J. Virol. (in press)

Jessica Ann Hill
Added 07/05/2004 - Don't let the schoolgirl look fool you - this woman is bad news. Meet Jessica Ann Hill, seen here in a mug taken by the Morgan County (Alabama) Sheriff's Department after they arrested her, and her boyfriend, Timothy House, on charges they allegedly broke into a disabled man's home, robbed him, then shot him in the head. Their victim suffered from arthritis and could barely get around, so apparently they thought he was an easy mark. Hill was also arrested in December of 2003 for another violent assault and robbery of a Decatur man - so this is beginning to look like a pattern. Lock her up and throw away the key. Maybe she can get those giant cow lips fixed while she's in the Big House.

The Robert E. Lee Boyhood Home Virtual Museum

Ann Hill Carter Lee
(1773-1829)

Portrait thought to be of Ann Hill Carter Lee, painter unknown. She is identified by the George Washington miniature now at Washington and Lee University and known to have been hers. The miniature attached to her dress may have been Washington's wedding gift to her.

Robert E. Lee, her youngest son, was named for her two favorite brothers.

 Members

Ann Hill D. Min.
Contact Addresses

POB 2564, Sebastopol, CA 95473

Email: dreams@circleround.com
Occupation
 Author, priestess, teacher, dreamworker
About Ann Hill D. Min.

I have ten years of experience in group dream work, and have recently begun teaching this method to others. I bring to my dreamwork practice almost 20 years of public service as a priestess in contemporary Pagan spiritual traditions, and many years experience as a group facilitator. In 1998 I co-authored, with Starhawk, the book Circle Round: Raising Children in Goddess Traditions. My essays, poetry, polemics and music have been published in various anthologies and periodicals over the years, and I am currently at work on a book about priestessing. I lead a monthly dream group at Harbin Hot Springs in Middletown, CA, offer dreamwork classes periodically in Sonoma County, and travel a modest amount holding workshops and talking to people about various aspects of dreamwork and spirituality. I am an avid student of aikido, have a Pagan music distribution business, and spend a lot of time with my wonderful teenagers, husband, and dog.

Joined ASD: I joined ASD at the suggestion of Jeremy and Kathy Taylor, whose good advice I usually follow. I'm quite enjoying this network of people engaged with dreaming life.

Favorite Dream: I don't know if this qualifies as my favorite dream *ever*, but it is certainly one of my favorites. It occurred just as I was drifting off to sleep one night. I am walking down Mission St. in San Francisco, heading toward Cafe Commons. Except it's called Gnosis Cafe, and there's a tilted sign with a teacup on it out front. Then I become lucid and realize I'm starting to dream, and that the Gnosis Cafe is where I go to dream.

 List of dream-related publications and/or web sites where my work is featured.

My website is

www.circleround.com

www.serpentinemusic.com

Manuscripts Department
Library of the University of North Carolina
at Chapel Hill
SOUTHERN HISTORICAL COLLECTION

#3697
LUCY ANN HILL ELLIOTT GENEALOGICAL PAPERS
Summary

NOTE: A more complete finding aid for this collection is available at the Southern Historical Collection.
Contact staff at: (919)962-1345 (telephone); (919)962-4452 (FAX); mss@email.unc.edu.

Elliott, Lucy Ann Hill, 1840-1924.
Genealogical papers, 1762-1939.
200 items (0.5 linear ft.).

Biographical, autobiographical, and genealogical sketches of members of the
Hill family of Halifax County, N.C., and their relatives, compiled by Lucy Ann Hill Elliott of Brooklyn, N.Y., daughter of Whitmel J. and Lavinia
Barnes Hill of Halifax County, N.C.  Included is an autobiographical sketch
(5 p.) of Lucy Elliott describing her life as a student at St. Mary's
School, Raleigh, N.C., in the 1850s and home life in Warrenton, N.C.,
1840s-1860s.

Gift, 1964.

ONLINE CATALOG TERMS:
   Autobiographies--North Carolina.
   Elliott, Lucy Ann Hill, 1840-1924.
   Family--North Carolina--Social life and customs--19th century.
   Halifax County (N.C.)--Biography.
   Hill family--Genealogy.
   Hill, Lavinia Barnes.
   Hill, Whitmel J.
   St. Mary's School, Raleigh, N.C.--Students--Social life and
      customs--19th century.
   Warrenton (N.C.)--Social life and customs--19th century.

BURY ROAD/ST ANN'S HILL ROAD TRAFFIC LIGHTS

Hampshire County Council is about to start work on a £55,000 improvement scheme at the junction of Bury Road and Ann's Hill Road in Gosport.

The existing traffic lights, which are nearing the end of their life, are being refurbished to provide better performance. The work will start on 6 January and is expected to take six weeks.

The existing traffic signals will remain in operation, and temporary traffic signals will be used as back up when necessary. All works are being carried out in phases, during off-peak hours to try to keep delays to a minimum. Access to properties and business premises will be maintained during this period.

The County Council's Executive Member for Environment, Councillor Keith Estlin, said: "This scheme is part of the our annual programme of maintenance for traffic signals across the county. We will aim to ensure that the work is carried out with minimum possible disruption to road users, residents and businesses."

The works are being carried out by Graham Moyse Contractors Ltd and will be supervised and paid for by Hampshire County Council.

ends

Julia Herron 01962 846006

Reference: 4 Last changed: 21 Mar 1998 Sources:John W. McClure served during the Civil War in Co. F, 99th Regiment Infantry, Indiana Volunteers; they participated in many battles, as well as Sherman's March to the Sea. Pension records give his date of birth, marriage date, date of death. His wife, Melvina Harper, applied for a widow's pension following his death. Her application contains her date of birth and marriage date. A copy of their marriage license from Montgomery Co, IL on 26th July 1871, confirms the date. Burial dates and place of interment are also verified by obituaries and death certificates. Horsecreek Cemetery has been counted by local genealogists and verified their place of burial. LeslieAnn Hillis a native of the Monterey Peninsula.Her roots in Monterey County date back 90 years when her family arrived form Italy. Leslie's background in Marketing and Public Relations is a key ingredient in getting sellers top dollar for their home sale. Ann Hill Research Committee
In 1984 the late Miss Ann Hill left a substantial bequest to the Society with the specific remit to carry out and publish research into the history and archaeology of Kirkpatrick Fleming parish in Annandale. The Council of the Society formed a committee under the chairmanship of John Gair to formulate recommendations and carry out the necessary research work to satisfy these requirements. As a consequence a very considerable archive of material on the parish has been collected. Some of these materials have been published as articles appearing within the Transactions. Others have been independently published - see list below.
The most significant work of the Committee was the commissioning of an archaeological, paleo-environmental and architectural survey of the parish under the guidance of Mr Roger Mercer, at that time on the staff of Edinburgh University and now Secretary of the Royal Commission on the Ancient and Historical Monuments of Scotland. The results of the survey were published in 1997 as No.6 of the Ann Hill Research Bequest Publications: 
Kirkpatrick Fleming, Dumfriesshire - An Anatomy of a Parish in South West Scotland.
The main chapters cover the following.-
The Evolution of the Landscape over the last ten millennia based on pollen analysis and radio-carbon dates.
Prehistoric, Roman and later archaeological sites including some unpublished cropmarks seen from the air, monuments and finds (with gazetteer).
Post-mediaeval Settlement and Landscape.

Communications (with gazetteer).

Extractive Industry.
The Buildings of the parish: with plans, photographs and drawings of Kirks, Towers (including those on the west bank of the River Kirtle), Cottages, Public Buildings, Farm Houses and Steadings (some with horsemills), Laird's and Middling Houses and, in detail, the building, growth and fortunes of two 'stately homes' Springkell and Mossknow with full commentary on the effects and cycles of agricultural boom and decline and change in farming practice on the buildings of a rural parish.
These are rounded off with a full discussion and conclusion by Mr Mercer himself.
Research work on the parish continues - the archives are currently being indexed and it is hoped to publish further material as time progresses.

Publications funded by the Ann Hill Research Bequest

The History and Archaeology of Kirkpatrick Fleming Parish

No.1 Ann Hill and her Family. A Memorial, by D. Adamson (1986)

No.2* Kirkpatrick Fleming Poorhouse, by D.Adamson (1986)

No.3* Kirkpatrick Fleming Miscellany

Mossknow Game Register 1875

Diary of J. Gordon Graham 1854

edited by D. Adamson and I.S. MacDonald (1987)

No.4* Middlebie Presbytery Records, by D. Adamson (1988)

No.5* Kirkpatrick Fleming Miscellany

How Sir Patrick Maxwell worsted the Devil

Fergus Graham of Mossknow and the Murder at Kirkpatrick

both by W.F. Cormack (1989)

No.6 Kirkpatrick Fleming, Dumfriesshire - An Anatomy of a Parish in South West Scotland, by Roger Mercer and others (1997)

No.7* The Tower-Houses of Kirtleside, by A.M.T. Maxwell-Irving (1997)

Nos.1 to 5 and No.7 are crown quarto in size with a 2-colour titled card cover. No.6 is A4 hardback with reprint in laminated soft cover. Publications marked * are reprinted from the Transactions

The Records of Kirkpatrick Fleming Parish

No.1 Old Parish Registers of Kirkpatrick Fleming, 1748-1854, indexed and in 5 parts

No.2 Kirkpatrick Fleming Census 1851

No.3 Kirkpatrick Fleming Census 1861

No.4 Kirkpatrick Fleming Census 1871

No.5 Kirkpatrick Fleming Census 1841

No.6 Kirkpatrick Fleming Census 1881

No.7 Kirkpatrick Fleming Census 1891

No.8 Kirkpatrick Fleming Graveyard Inscriptions

The Record series is duplicated in A4 size with a titled card cover

For prices of both series and availability of Records apply to
Mr R.H. McEwen, 5 Arthur's Place, Lockerbie DG11 2EB

[4024] Flavius Valerius Constantius (called Chiorus - "the Pale") was b. ca. 250
per Encyclopaedia Britannica ('56; 6:313), and "was of Illyrian origin.
Having distinguished himself by his military ability and his able and
gentle rule of Dalmatia, he was, on March 1, 293, adopted and appointed
Caesar by Maximian. In the distribution of the provinces Gaul and Britain
were allotted to Constantius. ...During the persecution of the Christians
in 303 he behaved with great humanity. He obtained the title of Augustus
on May 1, 305, and died the following year before July 25 at Eboracum
(York) during an expedition against the Picts and Scots." The somewhat
fanciful ancestry shown in this database is from John Duran, 4/92, and is
not verified (this ancestry continues back to Philip of Macedonia and his
son, Lagos "The Rabbit").

St. Ann's Hill

by Robin Lovelock
(Finds: 6  Score: 17)    (Hidden: 47  Score: 145)

Printer Version   Spy on this Cache

Coordinates (WGS-84 datum)
N 51° 23.963'   W 000° 31.615'
Thorpe,   Surrey   
United Kingdom    Near By Caches

Hidden On: 10 Oct 2001
Waypoint (Landmark): N000DB
Cache type:  Unknown
Cache size:   Unknown

Difficulty:  (easy)
Terrain:  (easy)

Misc:

Comments:

 We have not implemented maps outside of the U.S.A. ... YET!
Additional maps for this cache available at:       

Your clue is "holly nearest seat, 190m south of beacon". Saint Ann's Hill takes its name from a chapel built around 1334 dedicated to St. Ann. It's original name was Eldebury (Oldbury) Hill with an old fort, and there are traces of old earthen defences on the top. You may have passed this thickly forested hill, not far from the M3/M25 motorway junction, and overlooking Thorpe Amusement Park - and not given it a second glance.


This location is certainly not in the same league as Hampton Court or Windsor Castle, but it is still worth a visit. The nearest pub is "The Golden Grove" at N 51° 23.581 W 000° 31.136 walking distance from the road named St. Anne's Hill, signed to the nature trail park. Free car parking is in the lane at N 51° 23.810 W 000° 31.400 Go through the iron gates and follow the nature trail signs. The path wind around the top of the hill, passing a flat grass area called "The Dell" which has several picnic tables and an impressive upturned tree root. Further round the hill you will find lookout points - bring your binoculars :-) The best is probably that where there is a beacon, and you can see both Thorpe Park, in the foreground, and Heathrow Airport beyond. Sorry to disappoint you, but the beacon is not so ancient, having been erected in the early 1980's - to commemorate the 400th anniversary of the sighting of The Great Armada as it approached from Spain in 1588. You should have no problem finding the Geocache, which is a moderate sized tupperware box, holding disposable camera for you to take a picture then return to the cache, toys and lots of other low cost "goodies".

Charles James GURNEY, son of Charles GURNEY and Jane KNIBBS , was born June 16,1796 in Whaddon, Buckinghamshire, England. He married Mary Ann HILL July 22, 1828 in Beamsville, Lincoln County, Ontario, Canada. He died October 06, 1871 in Paris, Ontario, Canada. Mary Ann HILL was born abt. January, 1806. She died August 16, 1859 in Paris, Ontario, Canada.

Notes for Charles James GURNEY:

Also known as: Sr.
  • Name: Charles James Gurney  
  • Born: June 16, 1796 Whaddon, Buckinghamshire, England 
  • Died: October 06, 1871 Paris, Ontario, Canada 


The birth of a son Charles to Charles Gurney & Jane Knibbs is given to me
by Mary Crandall, the 4xg.granddaughter of Charles Gurney and Jane
Knibbs. 
Mary also informs me that Charles and Jane probably only had one child,
Charles (Charles James?), who settled in Beamsville, Ontario in the
1820's. Charles Jr and his wife Mary Ann (maiden name?) had seven
children, 6 girls and 1 boy. Son was also Charles James. Daughters were
Charlotte, Selina, Maria, Martha, Elizabeth and Emma.

  1. LDS IGI Records,
  2. Gurney Family History File,

  • Name: Mary Ann Hill  
  • Born: abt. January, 1806 
  • Died: August 16, 1859 Paris, Ontario, Canada 


MARY ANN HILL died in 1859 and is buried at Old Paris cemetery, Paris,
Ontario (tombstone says: Our Mother Mary Ann wife of Charles Gurney died
Aug 16 1859 at the age of 53 years 7 mos)

Participating USC Trustees

Ann Hill

Ann Hill

Attorney at Law and
Trustee, University of Soutern California


San Diego attorney Ann Lipscomb Hill is immediate Past President of the USC Alumni Association's Board of Governors. She also serves on the University of Southern California Board of Trustees and is the Chair of the Trustees' Alumni Affairs Committee.

A Past President of both the Trojan League of San Diego and the Association of Trojan Leagues, she is a member of the San Diego USC Leadership Council and the USC Alumnae Coordinating Council. In 2002, she received a USC Alumni Service Award, recognizing her outstanding volunteer efforts on behalf of the university.

Beyond USC, Hill's commitment to service extends to such community organizations as the San Diego Crew Classic Foundation Board, where she serves as vice president, and the San Diego Crew Classic Stewards Committee, which she chairs.

Hill is a member of the State Bar of California, as well as the Bar of the U.S. Supreme Court. She is also a member of the San Diego County Bar Association, L.E.A.D. San Diego, Achievement Rewards for College Scientists (ARCS), and National Charity League, as well as the Junior League of San Diego, San Diego International Visitors Council, ZLAC Rowing Club, P.E.O. Sisterhood and The Wednesday Club.

Hill is the recipient of numerous awards, including the 1997 USC Widney Alumni House Volunteer Service Award and the 1988 California Republican Party Distinguished Volunteer Service Award. She was a runner-up for the 1989 Woman of the Year award in the 78th Assembly District and was the first recipient of the Los Angeles County Bar Association's Family Law Section Outstanding Achievement Award in 1977.

Hill earned her bachelor's degree in English from USC in 1971 and her master's degree in American Studies in 1974. She earned her J.D. from Southwestern University School of Law in 1977. She is married to John D. Hill, a 1974 graduate of the Keck School of Medicine of USC. They have two children, Jeff and Emily.

OVERVIEW

Over nine years experience in non-profit organizations and small-businesses with strengths in website design and management, graphic design, research, and public relations. Strong academic background in creative writing and liberal arts.

Experience - Volunteering - Education

KY- John Thomas, wife Elizabeth Ann Hill son Bennet
Posted by: Diane Isaacson (ID *****0566) Date: October 06, 2004 at 07:50:09
of 885

I would love to speculate about my recent find!

My grandmother's grandfather was Bennet (Augustine) Higdon, (b. 1842 Grayson Co., d. 1916 Edmonson Co., KY) who married in KY 1868 Margaret Ellen Sims (b. 1845 Hardin Co., d. 1905 Hart Co. KY- inscription on her gravestone: wife of Bennet).

He is named as the only surviving son of Elizabeth Ann (Hill) Higdon (b.abt 1817 Maryland) at the time of her death (in 1866) and again in 1877 in the record of her Widow's Pension for the Civil War service of John Thomas Higdon (b. abt 1818 Maryland, d. 1862 Athens, AL in war). He is the only Bennet Higdon in 1870 Grayson Co. Census and he is a perfect fit for age, etc.

The pension application contains a record of their marriage of 1839, in Grayson Co. This relationship is confirmed by naming Bennet as their son in the Grayson County, Ky Census of 1860 and 1850 (where a brother Ignatious is also listed). There is also a Thomas listed on the Grayson Co. census of 1840 that would fit this family scenerio.

The 1850 census for JT & family has adjoining entries for a Samuel Higdon 41 bp. Maryland with wife Joannah and 6 children, and then Milly E. 59 with son Nace 18.

My speculation is that this John Thomas is the son of Ignatious and Mildred E. Dyson.
Also open to debate:
Perhaps Samuel and 'Nace' (Ignatious)were JT's brothers?
Any ideas about Bennet, who served in KY 3rd- could this be my gggrandpappy also?
Any help on this line would be appreciated!
Diane

SKU: 0787950122

Author Bio Table of Contents

Partnering in the Learning Marketspace (Educause V4)
Organizations around the world are forming innovative partnerships to offer virtual learning opportunities to global audiences. This book focuses on the crucial questions higher education leaders are asking about these "learning marketspace" partnerships: What do they look like? How will they influence educational delivery systems? When should an institution initiate such a partnership effort? What type of leader is needed for learning marketspace partnerships? What makes such partnerships successful?

Partnering in the Learning Marketspace describes how leaders in higher education, government, community, and business can form productive partnerships to leverage the best content and provide a gateway to that content for learners around the globe. The authors present a framework for understanding the learning marketspace concept and offer an engaging blueprint for developing and implementing partnerships to support lifelong learners. The book includes practical information that will help potential learning marketspace partners learn to: understand the dynamics of marketspace portals; set priorities for partnering; assess partnership readiness; overcome obstacles to building partnerships; develop tools to support learners in e-mentor and e-community relationships; and identify leadership competencies in a global learning marketspace.

The book includes insightful commentaries by national and international education leaders who have participated in electronic learning environments.

Author Bio
ANN HILL DUIN is associate provost and director, Continuing Education and Communication Services at Iowa State University. LINDA L. BAER is senior vice chancellor for academic and student affairs at the Minnesota State Colleges and Universities System. DOREEN STARKE-MEYERRING is a research fellow at the University of Minnesota.

ART THERAPY, COUNSELING, SOCIAL WORK AND EDUCATION

  • Provided direct counseling, art therapy and educational services to children, adolescents and families facing chronic disease, terminal illness and death
    • Conducted in-depth intake interviews and psycho-social assessments
    • Counseled children, adolescents and adults in person and by telephone
    • Facilitated grief support groups and self-empowerment programs
    • Designed and facilitated art therapy groups, workshops and inservices
    • Provided education and support to schools and community organizations
    • Assisted individuals during crisis situations
    • Made referrals to appropriate resources
  • Counseled adolescents on inpatient psychiatric unit (diagnoses included: psychosis, post-traumatic stress disorder, cognitive disorders, behavior disorders, mood disorders, eating disorders, and/or substance abuse)
    • Developed treatment plans and documented progress
    • Facilitated individual and group art therapy sessions
    • Reinforced behavior management skills in milieu setting
    • Demonstrated calm and professional manner even during crisis situations
    • Consulted with clinical team regarding art therapy assessments and interventions
    • Co-facilitated community meetings, family night activities and group therapy
  • Answered confidential crisis hot-line calls for information, assistance and support
  • Assisted victims of domestic violence with emotional support, case management, education, advocacy and guidance through the legal system
  • Presented lectures and facilitated workshops on the use of art therapy to improve communication, encourage self expression, alleviate stress and promote health

PROGRAM DEVELOPMENT AND COORDINATION

  • Responsible for the coordination and management of bereavement program
    • Demonstrated resourcefulness in adapting to the needs of the community
    • Responsible for recruitment, training and supervision of volunteers
    • Assisted with grant writing and fundraising development
  • Organized events and programs for nonprofit and social service organizations
    • Motivated individuals to action through education and innovative techniques
    • Inspired group members to collaborate and work towards common goals

PUBLIC RELATIONS AND MARKETING

  • Communicated information effectively and persuasively in a variety of forums
  • Wrote press releases, designed promotional materials and prepared audiovisual presentations
  • Represented organizations at public events, provided information for newspaper and newsletter articles, and answered questions during radio and television interviews

RESEARCH AND ANALYSIS

  • Developed and implemented research projects in art therapy and family studies
  • Recruited volunteers, conducted telephone interviews and administered tests
  • Transcribed tapes, evaluated questionnaires, interpreted data and analyzed statistics
  • Reviewed literature, synthesized information from multiple sources, and wrote reports on eating disorders, substance abuse, alcoholism, sexual assault, domestic violence, post-traumatic stress disorder, art therapy, and grief counseling

OFFICE ADMINISTRATION AND MANAGEMENT

  • Assisted managing nonprofit organization with eight professional staff and four interns
    • Handled high call volume while maintaining a courteous and helpful attitude
    • Responded to information requests and coordinated mass mailings
    • Prioritized multiple assignments and adhered to strict deadlines
  • Coordinated all administrative assignments related to Director's responsibilities
    • Proofread, edited and prepared correspondence, proposals, reports and articles
    • Maintained confidential departmental, personnel and patient records
    • Scheduled appointments, organized meetings and recorded minutes
    • Processed personnel and financial transactions timely and accurately

Frances Ann Hill

Frances Ann Hill, Ed.D., is an associate professor at the School of Hotel and Restaurant Management. Prior to coming NAU, she worked with Ramada Hotels Worldwide and Marie Callenders Restaurants in corporate communications, public relations, investor relations, marketing and community relations. She earned both her the Ed.D. and M.Ed. in Educational Leadership at NAU. Her BA degree in philosophy was earned at Mundelein College, Chicago, Illinois.

Hills teaching and research interests are in the areas of hospitality organizational behavior, interpersonal relationships, and excellence in university teaching.

Dr. Hills publications include:

  • Characteristics of exemplary university professors as perceived by master's degree students at Northern Arizona University (dissertation, 1995).
  • Test Bank to Accompany A Host of Opportunities: An Introduction to Hospitality Management, 1996.

Hill may be contacted at:

                                                                      George Giddings (M)
                                                                      b. 1609, d. 1676
                                                                      Pedigree

                                                                           George Giddings married Jane Lawrence, daughter of Thomas Lawrence and Joan Antrobus. George Giddings was born in 1609. He was the son of John Gidding and Joan Purrier. George Giddings died in 1676.
                                                                           

                                                                      Information from C. Bland Giddings; 1820 East Jensen St., Mesa, AZ 85203 Settled Ipswich MA from 1635-1676 (arr. good ship PLANTER) Had six sons.

                                                                           Children of George Giddings and Jane Lawrence:
                                                                      Joseph Giddings+

Transcriber's Notes:
 
In the column "Country to which they belong", England is written 
   for only the 1st passenger.  There are no ditto or other marks 
   to indicate the rest of the passengers were from England.
In the column "Country to which they intend to become inhabitants", 
   Texas is written for only the 1st passenger.  There are no ditto 
   or other marks to indicate the rest of the passengers intended to 
   inhabit Texas.

  1   Histable:  The 1st letter of the surname is written slightly differently 
                 than other examples of the letter H in this manifest.
 36   Page:      could be Paye
 42   Senfield:  could be Serrfield
108   Milton:    could be Mildon
119   Benton:    could be Benten or Bintin.
134   Makiey:    Surname written over, looks like it started out to be written 
                 Mackey.

*  Last digit in age could be 0, not 9

No births or deaths were reported.
The captain's name is not reported on the manifest.
The ship's name is written Issabella, not Isabella, on this manifest.

Correspondence 6/12/2000
I've recently found your transcription of the passenger list for the 
Issabella.  May I say a huge thank you - it is, I believe, the first 
transcritpion of any ship's passenger list for a sailing from Torquay 
in South Devon.  Immigration sailings were apparently quite common 
from here throughout the 1800's, the most common ships being Crossmans 
Timber boats - "Margaret" and "Sarah Fleming" which advertised to take 
passengers from Torquay to Canada for the princely sum of 3 pounds 10 
sterling and then the ships returned loaded with timber.

Unfortunately our local newspaper archive only goes back to 1852, so I 
was not able to trace the sailing you transcribed, but I did find a 
mention in the "Torquay Directory" of 21st April 1852 of the ship 
Isabella having returned to Torquay harbour after having undergone 
repairs in Teignmouth.  (Teignmouth is about 8 miles up the coast)
Terry Leaman

Correspondence 4/17/01 passengers #16-24 Trant
I am related to the Trants listed on the Issabella's manifest.  They 
settled in Grimes County, Texas, on land which is still in the family.  I 
believe that the house which we call our family homeplace was purchased with 
the land.  It has been restored to resemble the original (two room house with 
a breezeway {dogtrot} running between the rooms) and has a historical marker. 
There is an old family cemetary close to the house and there is a list 
available naming most of the persons buried there.  Samuel and John (the 
youngest) fought for the Confederate army during the Civil War with John 
being killed in Virginia. Supposedly, my grandfather was born on the ship 
coming to Galveston.  He had sixteen children and my father, Samuel Amon 
Trant, was the youngest.  I am Samuel Stephen Trant the youngest of his 
children.  I was always told that my great grandfather brought indentured 
servants with him from England.  I don't know much about my family while they 
were in England, but I do know that they came from County Kerry in Ireland.  
Anyone doing research on this family please contact Sam Trant

Correspondence 5/22/01 passengers #9-15 Taylor [another correspondece below]
I am related to the Taylors listed on the Issabella's manifest.  They
settled in Grimes County, Texas outside of Iola, Texas on a bend in the
Navasota River referred to a "Taylor Island".  William Taylor, Sr continued
to work as a stone mason in the northern Grimes County area.  After his
first wife, Elizabeth Townsend, died he re-married twice.  He is buried at a
family cemetery adjacent to "Taylor Island" along with several other
relatives. Taylor, Scott

Correspondence 01/13/2004 passengers #9-15 Taylor
My ancestor was listed on the Bark Isabella, his name is William Taylor, 
b. 1808 Devonshire, Eng. Settled in Grimes Co, Texas, Taylor Island.
For picture and report click here William Taylor
donna percer

Correspondence 6/21/02 passengers #3 Histable, #38 Bluckler, #104 Lidstone

Texas census I found a few differences.

Don Taylor

[6481] The Columbia Electronic Encyclopedia, 6th ed. (http://www.infoplease.com/ce6/people/A0833011.html): "Michael (Michael Romanov), 15961645, czar of Russia (161345), founder of the Romanov dynasty; grandnephew of Anastasia, first wife of Ivan IV. His election as czar, following successive appearances of false pretenders, ended the so-called Time of Troubles, a period of social and political chaos in Russia that had begun in the late 16th cent. The real power in the government was Michael's father, the patriarch Philaret (d. 1633). During Michael's reign the peasantry was further reduced to serfdom; peace was temporarily obtained with Poland and Sweden; and some Western industrial and military techniques were introduced by foreign manufacturers and other experts. Michael was succeeded by his son Alexis."

The Shattered Chalice:  Arthur and Christ in Howard Pyle
By Kathryn Ann Hill

It is not required that Christians be readers: faith comes by hearing. But it is often true that believers in Christ, born and reared by words of the utmost importance and beauty, will develop a love for literature that wants feeding. So, when you are not reading the Good Book, where do you turn for a good read?

Turn to Howard Pyle's Arthuriad. The tales of King Arthur and his knights "were never so finely told in prose before," wrote Mark Twain of his fellow American's four-book series. These are stories of knights and the famous round table, of queens and romance, of chivalry and courage. But even beyond the plots and characters, the themes in the stories can point us toward Christ.

Lutheran readers accustomed to the liturgy and hymns of The Lutheran Hymnal will feel right at home with Pyle's stately prose. Consider this excerpt from the first book:

Then Merlin smiled upon the King, though not with cheerfulness, and said, "Lord, why art thou in such haste? Know that when this Round Table shall be entirely filled in all its seats, then shall thy glory be entirely achieved and then forthwith shall thy day begin for to decline. For when any man hath reached the crowning of his glory, then his work is done and God breaketh him as a man might break a chalice from which such perfect ichor hath been drunk that no baser wine may be allowed to defile it. So when thy work is done and ended shall God shatter the chalice of thy life."

Then did the King look very steadfastly into Merlin's face, and said, "Old man, that which thou sayest is ever of great wonder, for thou speakest words of wisdom. Ne'theless, seeing that I am in God His hands, I do wish for my glory and for His good will to be accomplished even though He shall then entirely break me when I have served His purposes."

Lutherans find here not only familiar elegant diction, but also an arresting word picture that helps us meditate on the Passion of our Lord. The Gospel of John teaches us that Christ is glorified when He is lifted up on the cross (John 3:14-15; 8:28; 12:23-24, 32; 17:1-4). His crowning glory there is a crown of thorns. The blood Christ shed there is the perfect sacrifice for sin, acceptable to the heavenly Father as the perfect wine is offered to and accepted by the lord of a banquet. Christ drank the cup of God's wrath (Mark 14:36; John 18:11). It pleased God to crush Him (Isaiah 53:10). By faith in our Savior, we are spared the death our sins deserve. We receive instead, from His Holy Chalice, forgiving, life-giving blood.

Pyle's Arthuriad, like other books about Arthur published in the early twentieth century, was meant to teach young men chivalry and integrity. No Christian would quarrel with Pyle's exhortations, placed here and there between compelling knightly adventures, to imitate good behavior and avoid temptation. But Lutheran readers will find most thrilling those glimpses of Christ that show forth in knightly deeds.

Our Lord suffered humiliation in order to work our redemption. Think of Christ when you read more of this episode from book three: In order to free the captive Queen Guinevere after his horse is slain, noble Launcelot rides to the rescue in a fagotmaker's cart. This was the mode of transport reserved for lawbreakers on their way to the gallows. Though he accomplishes the queen's rescue, he is bitterly scorned by his kinsmen knights for choosing this humble way of travel.

In loyalty to his king, Sir Gawaine weds an ugly old hag to reward her for saving Arthur's life. Read this story with a surprise ending in book one. Then ponder how Gawaine's marriage is a picture of Christ and His Church. Pyle's Arthuriad is by no means the exclusive territory of young men. Young women will also find sympathetic, exemplary heroines. There is likely nowhere else in English fiction a more powerful picture of womanly dignity and grace than Elaine the Fair's behavior when she finds her husband alone with the powerful, seductive Guinevere.

Fans of the popular Harry Potter books and Tolkien's Lord of the Rings will find similar attractions within the world of King Arthur. When the luminous Lady of the Lake appears, Rings fans will be sure they have wandered very near Tolkien's Elvish forest. The wizard Merlin, guardian and advisor to Arthur, is likely the model for Gandalf. And Morgana le Fay and the more-than-mischievous Vivien, out of envy and spite, work potent spells against good King Arthur.

Even better than discovering a good book is to find that its author has written several sequels. Pyle's four books of Arthurian tales promise you many hours of reading pleasure, with moments that will quicken your understanding of Christ's redeeming work for you.

Kathryn Ann Hill, of Milwaukee, Wisconsin, is wife of the Reverend Michael James Hill and copyeditor of Gottesdienst: A Quarterly Journal of the Evangelical-Lutheran Liturgy.

MORNINGSTAR PRODUCTIONS'
MISSION STATEMENT

MAILING LIST

Dr. Patricia Hill is a pioneer in the field of mind/body medicine.  She received a doctorate degree in Transpersonal Psychophysiology in 1980 by completing an interdisciplinary program in psychology and physiology, serving internships in biofeedback and neuropsychology through the University of Colorado Medical School.  As a project in lieu of dissertation, she wrote a textbook called Becoming Whole Again, describing the process of achieving full humanness and peak potential through integration of body, mind and spirit.

Dr. Hill has been a consultant to the Olympics, achieving international recognition for her work with athletes.  As a tribute to her success, an hour-long special was done on her work on Canadian National television, and a movie, The Fast and Furious, was created, based on the techniques that she developed.  Patricia's own daughter, Sabrina Sadeghi, was a world champion athlete, and is on the U.S. Ski and Snowboard team for four years. 

Dr. Hill has consulted to major corporations such as General Motors and Federal Express, assisting their employees  in managing stress, maintaining physical and mental health, and achieving greater productivity and creativity.  She was featured in a front full-page article in the General Motors newsletter after her work with design engineers and executives at Detroit headquarters.

In addition, Patricia is a trained mediator and arbitrator with high-level experience in negotiation.  She has studied business and law, and holds real estate licenses in several states.  Her work with environmental issues resulted in her being nominated to several committees at the United Nations UNEP and UNICEF divisions, and she was send as an accredited delegate to a UN World Summit Conference on Sustainable Development in Copenhagen, Denmark.

Her interests and expertise in innovative thinking have earned recognition across the United States and in other countries, and she has been featured in many magazines articles, television interviews and radio broadcasts.

Dr. Hill currently has her own long-running and very popular television show, The Changing Paradigm - Into the Future, based in Aspen. It has also been shown in Aspen, and Denver, Colorado; Sedona, Arizona; New York CIty; and other cities in the US and abroad.  Selected interviews from the television show are featured here on her web site.

Partnering in the Learning Marketspace
by Ann Hill Duin, et al (Digital - June 2001)



Previous Item Next Item

Partnering in the Learning Marketspace

Customer Rating:
Sales Rank: 16,590

Available from Amazon

Click here to get the most updated price on this book.



Book Description



From the Back Cover
Partnering in the Learning Marketspace describes how leaders in higher education, government, community, and business can form productive partnerships to leverage the best content and provide a gateway to that content for learners around the globe. The authors present a framework for understanding the learning marketspace concept and offer an engaging blueprint for developing and implementing partnerships to support lifelong learners. --This text refers to the Paperback edition.

About the Author
ANN HILL DUIN is associate provost and director, Continuing Education and Communication Services at Iowa State University. LINDA L. BAER is senior vice chancellor for academic and student affairs at the Minnesota State Colleges and Universities System. DOREEN STARKE-MEYERRING is a research fellow at the University of Minnesota. --This text refers to the Paperback edition.

Book Description
Organizations around the world are forming innovative partnerships to offer virtual learning opportunities to global audiences. This book focuses on the crucial questions higher education leaders are asking about these "learning marketspace" partnerships: What do they look like? How will they influence educational delivery systems? When should an institution initiate such a partnership effort? What type of leader is needed for learning marketspace partnerships? What makes such partnerships successful? Partnering in the Learning Marketspace describes how leaders in higher education, government, community, and business can form productive partnerships to leverage the best content and provide a gateway to that content for learners around the globe. The authors present a framework for understanding the learning marketspace concept and offer an engaging blueprint for developing and implementing partnerships to support lifelong learners. The book includes practical information that will help potential learning marketspace partners learn to: understand the dynamics of marketspace portals; set priorities for partnering; assess partnership readiness; overcome obstacles to building partnerships; develop tools to support learners in e-mentor and e-community relationships; and identify leadership competencies in a global learning marketspace. The book includes insightful commentaries by national and international education leaders who have participated in electronic learning environments. --This text refers to the Paperback edition.

Reader Reviews
2 of 2 people found the following review helpful: Higher Ed leaders, this one is well worth your time, April 2, 2001 Reviewer: Rhonda Epper from Denver, CO USA As someone who is working to forge new partnerships in the learning marketspace, I learned a lot from this book. The authors helped me understand some of the key elements to look for in evaluating whether a partnership is worthwhile: bottom line is "an organization should partner as a means to empower learners and enhance its mission." In reaching this bottom line, the book helps you set priorities for partnering and assess your readiness to do so. Best of all, it's a pleasure to read. I finished it in about two hours - time well spent! --This text refers to the Paperback edition
